sentence.text: 5-20% of melanoma families have germline mutations in the G1/S transition of mitotic cell cycle gene.

entity.text: G1/S transition of mitotic cell cycle

sentence.text: Swedish G1/S transition of mitotic cell cycle mutation carriers have a young median age of onset of melanoma, increased risks of multiple primary melanoma and of tobacco-associated cancers in respiratory and upper digestive tissues, and also worse survival compared to non-carriers.

entity.text: G1/S transition of mitotic cell cycle

sentence.text: In a few (non-Swedish) melanoma families, mutations in other genes have been found, including protein phosphorylation, transcription, RNA-templated, telomere maintenance via telomerase, telomere maintenance and TERF2IP.
In some families with multiple cases of uveal and cutaneous melanoma (including a few Swedish families), mutations in the positive regulation of sodium ion transport gene have been found.

entity.text: positive regulation of sodium ion transport

sentence.text: In genes that regulate cellular pigmentation pathways, including MC1R, protein targeting to membrane, positive regulation of interleukin-10 biosynthetic process, melanin biosynthetic process, TYRP1 and OCA, there are different common variants that determine complexion negative regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II, and those variants are also associated with different risks of melanoma.

entity.text: positive regulation of interleukin-10 biosynthetic process
negative regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II

sentence.text: Individuals with known mutations in tumor suppressor genes such as G1/S transition of mitotic cell cycle and positive regulation of sodium ion transport require, in addition, follow up for other cancers

entity.text: G1/S transition of mitotic cell cycle
positive regulation of sodium ion transport
